captions.text: - I am half Scottish and half Mexican.

- Mexican, Puerto Rican,
Hawaiian, a little bit of Korean.

- 4/8 Japanese, 3/8
Mexican and 1/8 Filipino.

- I'm Filipino. My family
is from the Philippines.
- I'm just a white guy.
What it's like to be ambiguously ethnic

People assume you can
speak different languages
- I'm in Chicago, walking on the street,

minding my own business
and all of a sudden
there's this lady who's on the phone
trying to get ahold of her Uber driver.

All of a sudden, then she
sees me and she's like,
"Excuse me sir, can you take this call?

"This Uber driver, I think
he's Middle Eastern, Arabic.
"Can you handle this?
"Can you handle this?"

And I'm like, "You've
got to be kidding me"
and I just, kind of kept on walking.
But yeah, everyday occurrences.
Your name confuses people
- We had a substitute teacher
and he was reading off the roll,

like everyone does at
the beginning of class.
He got to Ryan Bargara.
I raised my hand and him thinking that
I was pretending to be Ryan Bargara.
And he actually asked,
"Where's the real Ryan Bargara?
"You're not him obviously because"

He almost said, "because
you're an Asian guy"
but he didn't.

You know, and that may
be one of the few times

where I wasn't sure if
I needed to be angry
or if I was more like, shocked.
I actually laughed in this situation
because I thought it was really funny.
But, like, when I thought about it later,

I was like, "Hmm, that
was kind of racist."
People assume what you are.
- We were hanging out and getting a drink,

just she and I for the
first time, I think.

We were kind of getting to
know each other a little bit
and she mentioned something,

"Oh well, cuz you're like
Colombian, right Jesse?"

I never mentioned anything
about who I am ethnically.

But she assumed Colombian,
which was so specific.

And I asked her, I'm like,
"No, I'm not Colombian.
"Where did you get that idea?"
And she said, "I don't know because
"you're kind of tan and you have dark hair
"you talk really fast."
I had to say, like, "I'm sorry.

"I'm like, Jewish and
Irish, I'm from the suburbs
"of Long Island, I'm not Colombian."
Boring dude from the suburbs.
People just want to know what you are
- I was trying online dating for a while.
Asian males were not very popular
for the online dating websites.
But the times I did get messages,

they were just trying to
figure out what I was.
Just like, "Oh, are you Indonesian?"
I'm like, "Nope. I'm Filipino."
Like, "Are you sure?"
Like, "Yup. Pretty sure."

Like, "Man, totally thought
you were Indonesian."
End of conversation.
So I didn't do a lot of online dating.
Didn't really work out for me.

- People can't really
put you inside of a box.
So people can't really say, like,
"Oh, you're Mexican?

"I'm going to assign this
stereotype to you" or
"Oh, you're white?
"I'm going to assign this stereotype."

Like, people just don't
really know what I am,

so they don't really
know what to expect of me
until I show them.
- I like to consider myself
an ethnic chameleon, if you will.
So if ladies are like,

"You know, I only like
light-skinned black guys"

I'm like, "Girl, I'm
right here," you know?

If it's like, "I can
only date Asian guys,"
like, "Well, I am part Asian."

title: What It's Like To Be Ambiguously Ethnic

comments.text:
I'm filipino/british and people always assume I'm indian or hawaiian or 
latina. I take it as a compliment because I find the woman there very 
beautiful!﻿

comments.text:
This happens to me all the time! I'm half white and half Spanish/Cuban. I 
just so happened to have dark hair and dark eyes like my mom but light skin 
like my dad, so people get really confused to the point that they start 
guessing. I've gotten half white half black (when I ask why they respond 
with "well your hair is extremely curly"), Asian, Mexican, and middle 
eastern. ﻿

comments.text:
I'm a full blooded Filipino but when I meet people for the first time 
they'll immediately ask if I'm Indian or am I half Indian. And because of 
those comments, I realized that I'm actually more of an Indian face than a 
Filipino. lol. And now, I can just practically agree because there's this 
one time when I was in a convenient store and there were 2 Indian 
foreigners who suddenly came up to me and asked me something, but obviously 
I didn't understand a thing because they're using Indian language. lmao. I 
just said, "I'm sorry but I'm a Filipino" and ran out of the store. ;A;﻿

comments.text:
And as a colombian-american. Guys..... dont race mix. It makes life

comments.text:
I am puertorican, black, white, and native american. I speak spanish and 
english but if you look at me, you will immediately think that I am all

people hear me speak spanish they think im just a black girl who just

look hispanic...I'm like....what the heck does hispanic look like? 
Sigh...oh well.﻿

comments.text:
Turks... already Ambiguously Ethnic for milennias. we have roots from

comments.text:
I'm mexican, now one of the most stupid thoughts people have is that 
mexican is a race, NO you stupid people, mexican is not a race mexican is a 
nationality, and as in mst of american countries there is a lot of diferent 
races with a same nationality, my backgrouns is spanis, italian, french, 
german, and native american now, all of this are not races are 
nationalities if i would talk about races i would say that theres is 5 
races, yellow, white, brown, red, black and a lot of sub-races. When i say 
to people that I'm mexican they said, Oh! but you dont look mexican. Is 
like if a usa citizen says I'm american I'm suposed to say, o but you don't 
look american, your'e black, or I'm mean how an american is suposed to look 
The USA is a country not a race.... stupid people _#﻿

comments.text:
I love these video cause they make it like only ethnic people have to deal

the funny thing is, I'm Colombian and i can say with certainty that the

comments.author: Juliana Ruiz

comments.text:
I really relate to this video . I'm half mexican, half filipino, and a tiny 
bit of ambiguous african. My skin is pretty brown, I have thick black hair, 
I'm 5'11, my eyes are slightly chinky but I have eyelid creases, my nose is 
kind of wide by my bridge is prominent, my lips are kind of full. My first 
name is original, my middle name is hispanic, and my last name is of french 
origin. I've been asked if I was samoan, indian, black, middle eastern, and 
other things that I'm not. I think its pretty fun to ask people what they 
think I am ethically. ﻿

comments.text:

I wish I was mixed race.  Unfortunately I'm not and neither is anybody in

comments.text:
I had an employee who is half White and half Taiwanese, but to people who 
don't know her most would guess she was Colombian, Venezuelan, Argentine, 
etc.  One time she had a Puerto Rican try to start a conversation with her 
about Puerto Rican pride.  When she told him she wasn't Puerto Rican the 
man didn't believe her and accused her of hating her own people.﻿
comments.author: International Observer

comments.text:
Why do people keep saying "quarter (Insert race here)" Wtf??I am pretty 
fucking positive that they only do that in the USA..That's FUCKING ANNOYING 
in my opinion.﻿
comments.author: Jan Arvid

comments.text:
+Melon Lord I understand,it's just annoying how they refer to them as such 
for some reason -.-
comments.author: Jan Arvid

comments.text:
+Jan Arvid Because saying "American" sounds weird. Pretty much nobody says 
"I am ethnically American." Even Native Americans generally either want to 
end the conversation by saying "I am Native American," or they say what 
tribe they hail from (I can say this because I lived in South Dakota for 12 
years).


Technically, it is not wrong for someone with colonial ancestry to say they 
are ethnically American. People from Peru or Mexico or wherever don't say 
they are "Spanish" or "Portuguese" or "French" or "Quechua" or anything, 
they say they are "Peruvian" or "Mexican".
comments.author: Melon Lord

comments.text: I am Colombian :D﻿

comments.text: Story of my life!﻿

comments.text:
I'm Mexican with French decent. I have very dark brown hair and eyes but my 
skin is pretty fair because of it. Also, my grandpa is blonde haired and 
blue eyed. He knows very little English and so one time we were just 
walking along and a white guy asked for directions. He looked completely 
shocked when my grandpa didn't answer and was even more shocked when I 
answered. ﻿
comments.author: Super_Sid

comments.text:
As a racially ambiguous looking person, I can totally relate to this. I 
always have people guessing/assuming what I am or as soon as they meet me, 
the first thing to come out of their mouth is, "what are you?'. So 
annoying.﻿

Aaaw come on, that stuff happens to blonde, white people too! "Are you

My brother gets Samoan I get half black and half Pacific Islander and we

comments.text:
All people are ethnic or have an ethnicity. Kinda lame buzzfeed perpetuates

comments.text:
What's with the sad sounding music? Do people really get that butthurt over

comments.text:
Half german with Scottish roots in the 1600s, 1/4 african american and 1/4 
cherokee native american.... someone thought I was Hawaiian and other 
people think I'm just black, or latin.﻿
comments.author: Auggusst

comments.text:
I'm black but people think I'm mixed or something else all the time. I'm 
light skinned so I guess I look like I could be a lot of different other 
ethnicities. I've had people come up to me and start speaking Spanish and 
they get really pissed off when I'm like "Uhhhh….sorry I don't speak 
Spanish." People have asked me if I'm Hawaiian, Puerto Rican, etc…When I 
went to Mexico for vacation with my step sister (who also is ambiguously 
ethnic) everyone was shocked that we were Mexican and didn't know a lick of 
Spanish. It never really bothered me, just always thought it was kinda 
funny and strange.﻿
comments.author: Kareena D (kcd0226)

comments.text:
My mum is half welsh half Spanish and my dad is half Indian half Sri 
Lankan. :) it's cool﻿
comments.author: Lalitha Seshadri

comments.text:
I'm Filipino, Peruvian, Black American, Native American, Spanish and 
Chinese. People usually mistake me as an Indonesian, Japanese/Black, 
Korean/Black, any race from South America and a really dark Cambodian or a 
dark ass Vietnamese and when I grow my beard, people think I'm 
Pakistani....Idk why though. When people look at me, they have that "What 
the f*ck are you???" look on their faces. I find amusing :>﻿

comments.text:
so basically ethnicity doesnt include the country where you were born in. 
So an e.g is that i am born in Australia but i have 2 chinese parents. Does 
this mean that technically im Australian but ethnically im 100 percent 
chinese and that assuming that i have kids with a chinese ethnic person and 
my children do too, that all my relatives would be considered 100 percent 
chinese ethnically but technically from x country.﻿

comments.text:
I'm Canadian and Lebanese. I hate it when I tell people I'm middle eastern 
and they think I'm joking because I look white. I also hate it when they 
assume I just sit around all day eating sand and sending money to Isis. I'm 
also not Muslim, thank you very much.﻿
comments.author: wyatt tacey

comments.text:
I'm born in the US, lived 6 years in Poland and have a Polish mother, have 
a father and family from Cuba, and now live in Ireland... yup.﻿
comments.author: Black Griffon

comments.text:
I'm 1\4 Irish, 1\4 German, and 1\100 everything els.
Im white. I have an afro. Everyone always assumes I don't 1. Brush my hair 
( I once had a kid tell me to brush the raccoon of my head)
2. I don't wash it﻿
comments.author: Teresa Mullooly

comments.text:
I'm brazilian (half amerindian, half italian), but when I was living in 
Europe people assumed that I was from India or Pakistan. Actually, 
sometimes it was kinda funny, but other times it was uncomfortable. Once I 
was talking to a girl in a party, and she asked me to say sth in Hindi, I 
told her that I was brazilian and she simply didn't believe, she indeed 
asked me to see my passport. At this moment I was like.. "really?". She 
replied telling me that I didn't look like a brazilian. For real, I'd like 
to know how a brazilian is supposed to look like.﻿
comments.author: Thales Delaia

comments.text: "I'm just white". lol﻿
comments.author: Gabriel Dayot

comments.text:
I'm half white and half Guamanian. People always assume I am Hispanic 
though…﻿

comments.text: I know the struggle, my heritage is Mexican, Spanish, and French.﻿
comments.author: andres54322

comments.text:
the thing about India is, here every state has a language (or languages) 
and culture of its own. Now when people from one state settle in another 
state its almost like they have to go through a similar kind of scrutiny 
about where they're from, which community do they belong to and so 
on...it's kinda funny though.﻿
comments.author: Anita Das

comments.text:
As someone half Japanese and half white, this is my life. Lots of people 
guess, most are way off.﻿
comments.author: AsianWolfMan91

comments.text:
Got chinese, dutch, arabian and indonesian in me. People call me Korean, 
Chinese, Japanese but the people from said ethnicity calls me 
differently...﻿
comments.author: Ridhwan Abdurrahman

comments.text:
Trust me substitute teachers butcher my name almost 100% of the time. I get 
called Anal a lot :/ It's a real struggle :c﻿
comments.author: SSJ Vegito

comments.text:
My roots are : Croatian, German, English, Czech and Italian..... I've had 
people ask me if I'm Polish, Greek, Iranian, Russian...... ^^﻿
comments.author: Joshua Tovey

comments.text:
I'm always very interested to know people's stories, I like knowing where 
people are from or what cultural background they may have. I'm not trying 
to pigeonhole anyone or make people conform to stereotypes, I try not to 
make assumptions, I'm just curious.﻿
comments.author: Buffoon1980

comments.text:
I'm Filipino and every time I work first thing is that they speak Spanish 
to me. Yes I get that I'm dark skinned. Story of my life every day. ﻿
comments.author: Shaun Cayobit

comments.text:
I've always been good at spotting Filipinos. They have like the 
watered-down East Asian look. Almost like a hybrid between an East Asian 
and a Spaniard. They're a very unique and distinct people. You cannot miss 
them. And for some reason, I always get shocked looks when I ask a Filipino 
if he/she is Filipino. Their response has almost always been, "most people 
just assume I'm Mexican." And I'm like, how? But then again I'm from 
Maryland, which has a sizable Filipino community.﻿
comments.author: CzarJuliusIII

comments.text:
I'm 100% Filipino, yet on Singapore they kept on insisting that I was 
Malaysian. And in Canada, had a temp job and people asked if I'm Cuban 
because they kinda thought I looked like one. Another incident where 
someone asked if I am Mexican/Spanish because of looks and my name. FML. 
Stop doing this to us people!﻿
comments.author: stupord

comments.text:
Does anyone know the name of the first girl in the video? Thanks in 
advance. ﻿
comments.author: Reiley Palmer

comments.text:
I'm half Japanese, half Irish and I look like an adopted child if I'm with 
only one of my parents.﻿
comments.author: Minori

comments.text:
Im am Mexican-Irish-Spanish... In the US they ask me if I'm European or of 
i am speaking Italian or French while actually speaking Spanish. In my own 
country (Mexico) they speak to me in English because they assume I'm from 
the US. It happens to my boyfriend too. He's Mexican-Asturian.﻿
comments.author: Maria Munoz

comments.text:
I'm Canadian, German, Hispanic, and African American. And I speak English, 
Spanish, and French. Yay me. The problem is: people ask if I'm Asain, or 
Puerto Rican. I kind of like people questioning what I am. I usually go 
along with it, like "hell yeah I'm Columbian" lol ﻿
comments.author: Eyeful Of Eli

comments.text: French-Canadian*
comments.author: Eyeful Of Eli

comments.text:
I forgot to mention, my family always comments on my other race. Like my 
black fam(dad side): you don't like watermelon? You talk proper? You sleep 
with the air and fan on? that's your white side.
